displayed_text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yes, so again, with the caveat that it would be considered unconventional therapy – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - you know given that caveat if we both acknowledge that, I would be willing to consider that for you, especially if the studies don’t show any disease or metastatic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: disease is one. And if we were both informed that this is really not the conventional therapy and yet you still want to or agree to do it. But I think as long as it’s an informed decision, I’m willing to consider that.

Patient: Yeah. Well, I noticed it hurt, so I tried to take care of it. Iced it and everything else and then about a week later I noticed my leg was swelling and then it moved down my leg into my ankle. Doctor: And you went to the emergency room? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they found it Patient: They all freaked out. Even the doctors, everybody. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Patient: If I need it. Doctor: A baby aspirin once a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Atorvastatin forty milligrams once a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You’re on the bicalutamide? That’s the medicine for your prostate cancer? Family Member: He took him off of that. Patient: I was ready to say that. Doctor: Your Colace or the docusate to help soften your stools? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Folic acid one milligram pill a day? Patient: Yes.

Patient: I don’t think I’d have any trouble tolerating. Doctor: Yeah. It doesn’t seem like, from everything I’m gathering about this medication, it seems like it’s been easy to tolerate. There may be some infusion reaction or, you know-. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Some occasional side effects, but we’ll be monitoring your blood labs, liver function, kidney function, all of that, every time before we give you that injection. Family Member: So- Doctor: So you’ll be monitored. Patient: So when I do get, when do I get my tickets? Doctor: Well, once, first, you have to sign the consent and do all the screening. Then we can register you and start booking the, the tickets, and whatnot. Patient: Here’s the papers I sign? Doctor: This is not the paper. Doctor: We have to bring you- Family Member: He didn’t care.

Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: What’s your name? Family Member: K___ P____. He probably wouldn’t remember me. Doctor: I don’t know, he sometimes tends to remember a lot of the people he did… Family Member: Is he still in radiation oncology here? Doctor: He is. He just started back here within the last year. Before that he was at other hospitals. Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: So yeah. Family Member: That’s great. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: Thank you, thank you again. Doctor: That is amazing. Small world right. Family Member: Yeah. (Laughs)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. They do screening tests including an imaging test. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh they give you a treatment. At least my experience is then they keep you for a little bit and image you maybe once or twice after to look at how much your cancer took up the material. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on? Patient: Um, that’s it. Doctor: Uh, last time you talked to C_ about your fatigue at the end of the day. Patient: Eh, just tired at the end, at the end, after working all day. Doctor: Any pain anywhere? Patient: No. Doctor: Any belly pain?

Patient: No. I’m not freaked out. Doctor: You’re our movie star today. (door closes) Patient: No. Not at all. This this comes from… Doctor: How are ya. Patient: I am good. How are you? Doctor: Good, not too bad. Patient: Did you get your certificate? Doctor: My certificate? Patient: From the U_______. Doctor: I did! How did you know that? (pause) Patient: I – You you want me to be the best patient you’ve got, I… Patient: I have to know all that stuff. Doctor: Thank you. I’m now officially the Rudi Ansbacher academic scholar at U______.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: One is going to be for the PSA, one is going to be for the testosterone and another is going to be for the A1C. Patient: Uh hum. I was wondering if we can make it a weekly, a monthly routine of bloodwork like . I’d rather not do that. Doctor: You won’t have monthly from that perspective he or she can Patient: Okay. Doctor: - at least for the short term. If something changes in the future, it might have to be more frequently. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But for now uhm, (keyboarding sounds) Family Member: Eighth. Patient: February eighth, February.. Doctor: Twenty-seventh? Patient: Yeah. (sound of printer operating) Doctor: This is from the week of January eighth, two thousand eighteen. It doesn’t have to be that specific day.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And then, you have your PSA which is thirteen down to four point nine at your lowest, and back up to ten. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Previously, we’ve been letting people stay on the testosterone. They feel good plus their scans don’t look any worse. I think given that your PSA went up, you’re feeling good, and the scans are a little worse, maybe you should come off it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And think about what’s next. Patient: Yeah. What is next? Doctor: Yeah. That’s the hard part of the day. Uh well I guess the first question is you sort of came here specifically for this. Are you going to, do you want to stay here for the next or is the next, do you want to go somewhere, to shop around? Patient: No, no. I, I came here because Dr. T___ out at S__ say, say, oh, you know, certainly recommended it. I guess he’s part of this study too, so. Doctor: He is. He is. Patient: So uh he felt pretty strongly that coming here to participate but also to, to say here is- Doctor: Remind me again how you hooked up with him. Patient: Yeah. Through the urologist that I had that did the surgery. Doctor: Because you’re mostly east coast. You, you moved?
